content.title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
content.content: If P(x) is a polynomial of degree n, then P(x) has exactly n zeros, each of which may be written in the form a + bi where a, b are real, and some of which may be repeated.

content.title: Properties of Real Polynomials
content: Every real polynomial of degree n can be factorised into n complex linear factors, some of which may be repeated.
Every real polynomial can be expressed as a product of real linear and real irreducible quadratic factors (where Delta < 0).
Every real polynomial of degree n has exactly n zeros, some of which may be repeated.
If p + qi (q != 0) is a zero of a real polynomial then its complex conjugate p - qi is also a zero.
Every real polynomial of odd degree has at least one real zero.

content.title: Finding zeros using complex conjugate pairs
content.problem: Suppose -3 + i is a zero of P(x) = ax^3 + 9x^2 + ax - 30 where a is real. Find a and hence find all zeros of the cubic.

steps: Since P(x) is real, both -3 + i and -3 - i are zeros.
These have sum = -6 and product = (-3 + i)(-3 - i) = 10.
Therefore the zeros -3 +/- i come from the quadratic x^2 + 6x + 10.
The coefficient of x^3 is a. The constant term is 10 x (-3) = -30.
Equating coefficients of x^2 gives: 6a - 3 = 9, therefore a = 2
Equating coefficients of x gives: 10a - 18 = a, therefore a = 2
Therefore a = 2 and the linear factor is (2x - 3)

content.title: Finding zeros with purely imaginary zero
content.problem: One zero of ax^3 + (a + 1)x^2 + 10x + 15, a is real, is purely imaginary. Find a and the zeros of the polynomial.

steps: Let the purely imaginary zero be bi, b != 0.
Since P(x) is real, both bi and -bi are zeros.
These have sum = 0 and product = -b^2*i^2 = b^2
Therefore the zeros +/- bi come from the quadratic x^2 + b^2.
The coefficient of x^3 is a. The constant term is b^2 x 15/b^2 = 15.
Equating coefficients of x^2 gives: a + 1 = 15/b^2 ... (1)
Equating coefficients of x gives: ab^2 = 10 ... (2)
Therefore a = 2 and the zeros are +/- i*sqrt(5), -3/2.

content.title: Sum and Product of Roots
content.content: For the polynomial equation sum(a_r * x^r, r=0 to n) = 0, a_n != 0, the sum of the roots is -a_{n-1}/a_n, and the product of the roots is (-1)^n * a_0/a_n.

content.title: Derivation of Sum and Product Formulas
content.content: Consider the polynomial equation a_n(x - alpha_1)(x - alpha_2)(x - alpha_3)...(x - alpha_n) = 0 with roots alpha_1, alpha_2, alpha_3, ..., alpha_n. Expanding the LHS and equating coefficients gives: a_{n-1} = -a_n[alpha_1 + alpha_2 + alpha_3 + ... + alpha_n] and a_0 = (-1)^n * alpha_1 * alpha_2 * alpha_3 * ... * alpha_n. Therefore -a_{n-1}/a_n = alpha_1 + alpha_2 + ... + alpha_n and (-1)^n * a_0/a_n = alpha_1 * alpha_2 * ... * alpha_n.

content.title: Cubic Functions
content.content: The most basic cubic function is y = x^3. Its graph is shown with points (-2, -8), (-1, -1), (0, 0), (1, 1), (2, 8). Notice that: the graph is horizontal at (0, 0); as x approaches infinity, y approaches infinity; as x approaches negative infinity, y approaches negative infinity.

content.title: Properties of y = ax^3
content: The graph of y = ax^3 has shape curving up-right if a > 0, or curving down-right if a < 0.
As the size of a increases, the graph of y = ax^3 becomes steeper.
The graph of y = a(x - b)^3 + c is obtained by translating the graph of y = ax^3 by the vector (b, c).

content.title: Graphing cubic transformations

content.solution: The graph shows y = x^3 as a dashed curve through the origin, and y = (x - 2)^3 - 1 as a solid curve passing through (2, -1), which is the translation of y = x^3 by 2 units right and 1 unit down.

content.title: Behavior of Cubic Graphs at Zeros
content: If a > 0, the graph has shape curving up-right from bottom-left to top-right. If a < 0 it is reversed.
Every cubic polynomial must cut the x-axis at least once, and so has at least one real zero.

For a cubic of the form P(x) = a(x - alpha)(x - beta)(x - gamma) where alpha, beta, gamma are real and distinct, the graph has three distinct x-intercepts corresponding to the three distinct zeros alpha, beta, and gamma. The graph crosses or cuts the x-axis at these points.
For a cubic of the form P(x) = a(x - alpha)^2(x - beta) where alpha, beta are real, the graph touches the x-axis at alpha and cuts it at beta.
For a cubic of the form P(x) = a(x - alpha)^3, x is real, the graph has only one x-intercept, alpha. The graph is horizontal at this point.
For a cubic of the form P(x) = (x - alpha)(ax^2 + bx + c) where Delta < 0, there is only one x-intercept, alpha. The graph cuts the x-axis at this point.

content.title: Quartic Functions
content.content: A quartic function is a function of the form y = ax^4 + bx^3 + cx^2 + dx + e where a, b, c, d, and e are constants, a != 0. The simplest quartic function is y = x^4. Notice that: the graph opens upwards; the graph is 'flat' at (0, 0); as x approaches infinity, y approaches infinity; as x approaches negative infinity, y approaches infinity.

content.title: Properties of Quartic Graphs
content: For a quartic polynomial in which a is the coefficient of x^4: if a > 0 the graph opens upwards; if a < 0 the graph opens downwards.

If a quartic with a > 0 is fully factorised into real linear factors, then: for a single factor (x - alpha), the graph cuts the x-axis at alpha; for a square factor (x - alpha)^2, the graph touches the x-axis at alpha; for a cubed factor (x - alpha)^3, the graph cuts the x-axis at alpha and is 'flat' at alpha; for a quadruple factor (x - alpha)^4, the graph touches the x-axis and is 'flat' at that point.
If a quartic with a > 0 has one real quadratic factor with Delta < 0 we could have graphs with different shapes.
If a quartic with a > 0 has two real quadratic factors both with Delta < 0, the graph does not meet the x-axis at all.

content.title: Sketching quartic graphs
content.problem: Sketch the graph of: a) y = (3x - 2)(x + 3)(x + 1)^2, b) y = -(x - 3)^2(x + 2)^2

solutions.content: a > 0, so the graph opens upwards. The graph cuts the x-axis at 2/3 and -3, and touches the x-axis at -1. When x = 0, y = (-2)(3)(1)^2 = -6, therefore the y-intercept is -6.
a < 0, so the graph opens downwards. The graph touches the x-axis at 3 and -2. When x = 0, y = -(-3)^2(2)^2 = -36, therefore the y-intercept is -36.

content.title: Finding quartic equation from intercepts and points
content.problem: Find the quartic function P(x) which touches the x-axis at 2, cuts the x-axis at -3, and passes through (1, -12) and (3, 6).

steps: The graph touches the x-axis at 2, so (x - 2)^2 is a factor.
The graph cuts the x-axis at -3, so (x + 3) is a factor.
Therefore P(x) = (x - 2)^2(x + 3)(ax + b) where a and b are constants, a != 0.
Solving (1) and (2) simultaneously gives a = 2, b = -5.
